awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Automatic Text-Simplification and Reading-Assistance to Support Self-Directed Learning by Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Computing Workers
awd_abstract_narration:
While there is a shortage of computing and IT professionals in the U.S., there is underrepresentation of people who are Deaf and Hard of Hearing (DHH) in such careers. There is great diversity in the English reading skills among DHH Americans, who face challenges in the IT industry where regular upskilling is required throughout the working career.  This interdisciplinary research will focus on studying automatic text-simplification technologies as reading assistance to help DHH individuals keep up with rapidly changing technologies through self-directed learning, outside of a formal classroom setting.  The research team consists of experts in natural language processing (NLP), human-computer interaction (HCI), accessibility, and Deaf STEM education research. The resources and technologies developed for this project will be adaptable to other languages and text domains (e.g. medical information for lay readers), benefiting a wide range of populations (e.g. children, non-native speakers, people with reading disabilities).

Prior text-simplification research for specific user groups focused on preliminary data collection or classical NLP methods, and little HCI research has explored design options for reading-assistance systems. This project will fill this critical gap in research and will investigate the learning and reading-assistance needs of upskilling DHH computing workers, design parameters influencing usability of reading-assistance tools, new training data and methods for text simplification tailored to specific reader groups and technical genres, automatic and human-based evaluation methods, and the impact of such tools on heutagogical learning. The methods will include interview and survey research with DHH computing workers, prototyping and testing of design variations, creation of parallel simplification corpora, readability annotation of lexicon and texts by DHH individuals, NLP research on domain adaptation and syntax-based neural machine translation for text simplification, and observation of real-world deployment of a prototype with DHH students and recent graduates from computing-related programs at the National Technical Institute for the Deaf (NTID).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
While there is a shortage of computing and IT professionals in the U.S., there is underrepresentation of people who are Deaf and Hard of Hearing (DHH) in such careers. There is great diversity in the English reading skills among DHH Americans, including some DHH individuals with lower levels of English reading literacy. This poses a challenge for computing professionals who must regularly "upskill," i.e., teach themselves about rapidly changing technologies throughout their career. In this project, we investigated new automatic text-simplification technologies for reading assistance, i.e., tools that can automatically simplify the English text in a document or on a webpage, on demand, upon request.  In this project, we investigated how DHH individuals with lower English literacy engage in reading activity and learn about topics for their work currently, as well as whether automatic tools for simplifying text would be useful for these individuals. 

The text-simplification and reading-assistance technologies investigated in this project may benefit the significant numbers of people who are DHH in the U.S. who face barriers in pursuing careers in STEM fields due to challenges in accessing English text content. Thus, the broader impacts of this project include the societal benefits of learning how to best design and evaluate reading-assistance and simplification technology to support self-directed learning by DHH individuals, including those with lower English literacy. Such technology will transform the independence and employment opportunities for these users, especially those working in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) fields.

In this collaborative research project, the human-computer interaction aspects of the work occurred primarily at Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), and the natural language processing aspects of the work occur primarily at Georgia Tech.  The human-computer interaction side of this project conducted at RIT had the following key contributions:

Through interviews and a survey, we learned about the requirements of DHH individuals in the computing field, which motivated further technical and design work on automatic text simplification (ATS)-based tools. Participants frequently read on electronic devices to learn about new topics for their work, and they had strong interest in these tools. Our study also revealed a prioritized list of the most frequent workarounds DHH computing workers currently use to understand complicated text and reading purposes for which they would be interested in using tools. Our work uncovered how DHH readers were concerned about social accessibility issues, e.g., privacy about using these tools in a workplace.

Our project also investigated how to best design a research study that evaluates automatic text simplification tools among DHH participants, including how to best evaluate the fluency and complexity of the texts that result from this technology.

The final phase of our work focused on the design of ATS-based reading assistance tools for DHH adults, including identifying that DHH users perceived a benefit from tools that provide lexical simplification, i.e., replacing complex words with simpler alternatives.  We also found that DHH users preferred systems that provided greater levels of autonomy, i.e., giving them control over what parts of a text were simplified and revealing which portions of a text had been modified.  In studies with a prototype system for simplifying text on webpages, we investigated preferences of DHH users among different variations of the system, to identify preferred design settings for such systems.  In a final evaluation study, we observed DHH users interacting with a text simplification tool while completing a reading task with complex technical texts, and we measured how the use of such tools influenced reading behavior and led to measurable benefits for readers.
